page.title: 04WOODLAND IN BIBURY AREA
page.content: Roughly one square kilometre of woodland in the Bibury area consists mainly of beech, other hardwoods and some softwoods. More fruit bearing trees have been planted for the wildlife and in the future three small woods are to be planted for game coverts. Spot thinning takes place in established woods to let the sun in to encourage wildlife. The hardwoods are sold for furniture making, the smaller timber for pit props and the very small for firewood. The softwood timber is used on the farm for fencing. First year seedlings up to whips are planted and great care must be taken to protect the young trees from rabbit and squirrel damage. Quite a few trees are lost through disease. In 1976 a lot of beech were lost through drought.
